Award.AwardTitle: Building Capacity to Retain Underrepresented Students in STEM Fields

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Education and Human Resources

Award.AbstractNarration:
The NSF invests in a number of programs targeting underrepresented populations and institutions relative to its meeting its goals for broadening participation in STEM. This workshop provides minority serving institutions with an opportunity to engage in dialogue about effective ways to create, implement, and evaluate models of intervention that will advance knowledge about retaining underrepresented minorities in STEM fields. It will advance knowledge in life science and the biosciences for K-12 and undergraduate students attending local schools or eligible minority-serving institutions. The workshop will focus on assisting minority serving institutions with use of research designs, and review of best practices for intervention shown to be effective in helping underrepresented student cope with chronic stresses that interfere with their retention in STEM fields and careers. The target audience for the workshop will be the participating institutions and their undergraduate students, in partnership with local K-12 schools.

In collaboration with Quality Education for Minority and MERAssociates, Rutgers University Newark will provide a unique setting to convene more than 100 participants to attend the workshop. The participants will include deans and/or department chairs; STEM faculty; educational researchers, and institutional representatives such as Vice Presidents of Academic Affairs, Provosts, or other administrators. The participants will work in teams of 4-5 to address science research topics and activities related to curriculum development, teacher support, and student engagement. Outcomes from the workshops will provide insights about successful strategies, areas of future research, and awareness about the need for better intervention models that support underrepresented minority students in STEM.

Institution.Name: Rutgers University Newark
Institution.ORG_LGL_BUS_NAME: RUTGERS, THE STATE UNIVERSITY OF NEW JERSEY

POR.DRECONTENT:
In collaboration with Quality Education for Minorities (QEM) and MERAssociates (MERA), Rutgers University-Newark host a two-day research and grant writing workshop for teams of administrators and faculty of minority-serving intuitions (MSIs) in the northeast region of the United States of America. Thirty-four MSI universities participated, each sending four- or five-member teams. The goal of the capacity-building project was to increase the NSF-sponsored research funding portfolio of MSIs for projects specifically designed to establish, extend, or sustain underrepresented students in STEM academic fields and careers. By broadening of the engagement and participation of individuals in STEM fields, the project sought to contribute overall to improve the well-being of nation by widening economic and social opportunities and deepening its global competitiveness.

As the coordinating backbone for the collaborative impact of the workshop, QEM and MERA provided workshop design and content, evaluation, and post-workshop follow-up. As the regional host, Rutgers University-Newark was responsible for all local organizational matters including workshop venue preparation and catering needs; recruitment of institutional teams from the northeast region’s MSIs; participant travel, lodging arrangements, local transportation, and stipends. MSIs institutional teams consisted of administrators and STEM faculty.

Intellectual Merit

Through synergistic activities among three collaborating entities—QEM, MERA, and Rutgers-Newark—and two other regional host universities, the project sought to down a profoundly entrenched and complex social problem: involvement of underrepresented groups in STEM academic fields and careers. In the partnership, the project provided three distinct workshops, to build the capacity of each region’s MSIs to prepare and submit competitive research and development project proposals to NSF DRL/Life STEM that establish, extend, or sustain underrepresented populations in STEM academic fields and careers. As such, the project extended the framework of collaborative impact (Kania & Kramar, 2011).

Broader Impact

Participation of institutional teams ensured stronger campus engagement in preparing proposals and sustaining effective external partnerships and collaborations. Project activities served to broaden the participation of MSIs in DRL and Life STEM programs to support national efforts toward STEM education and workforce development as well as innovations in STEM teaching and learning across the educational landscape. To ensure broader dissemination of information, QEM and Rutgers-Newark made available at their websites project-related materials including agendas and presentations. Rutgers-Newark and participating regional MSIs gained, shared, and disseminated knowledge on strategies that broaden the participation in STEM research among faculty researchers as well as practical ways to prepare competitive Life STEM proposals.

References

Kania, J., & Kramar, M. (2011). Collective impact. Stanford Social Innovation Review. https://ssir.org/images/articles/2011_WI_Feature_Kania.pdf
